Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Phase II: Grid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Grid-Connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES) IUCRC proposes renewal as a two-site I/UCRC, comprising personnel and facilities at the University of Arkansas (lead) and the University of South Carolina with a focus on developing the new knowledge, tools, hardware, software, and personnel that are required to pervasively insert power electronics into the 21st century power grid in ways that will strengthen and modernize the grid. GRAPES makes use of an already-developed facility for design, development,
test, evaluation, and standardization of distribution-level grid-connected power electronic equipment. This enables validation of research findings, and accelerated insertion of new solid-state equipment into the power grid at both source and load ends.

Power electronics in grid applications are essential to achieving efficient power systems of high reliability and resiliency. The I/UCRC in Phase II will train students and practicing engineers who will become qualified to develop and manage the next generation of power systems, thereby helping to mitigate the forecasted shortage of power engineers. GRAPES will establish new courses that will integrate research with education to make our students highly competitive in their ownership of unique skills and knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

  Technologies developed by GRAPES researchers increase the use of power electronics in grid-connected equipment.  This improves efficiency and reliability of equipment, saving the utility industry and their customers time and money. There are a number of project examples under demonstration either during Phase II or extending into Phase III. Some are listed here.
   One instance is the residential energy management device that saves consumers money and promotes residential renewables in a safe and efficient manner. The project involving phase balancing technology is currently in prototype phase at a distribution level for deployment in a utility partner grid. One project resulted in a nine-level cascaded h-bridge prototype.  Findings include a comparative analysis between Si and SiC devices as enabling technologies.  This helps industries understand and evaluate what types of devices using Si and SiC materials are most useful to their systems. One project developed a holistic 3-level (PE block, circuit, cabinet) device with integrated multi-objective optimization. The co-designed electro-thermal management, control and reliability approach will enable a longer lifetime.

    Additional teams having impact on industry partners including one developing a decentralized MG control architecture, outperforming the centralized architecture in delay mitigation and reliability. Test results demonstrate the robustness of the proposed system when applied to a decentralized control architecture for microgrids. Adopting four methods of failure detection speeds up the recovery process, as they guarantee a fast propagation of system updates among the controllers.

   Additionally, GRAPES work aligned with GRAPES strategic planning and Needs Document by developing a MPSST device and system that can enable smart distribution.  The work will lead to more controllable, reliable, and efficient distribution systems. The comparative analysis of one project provided design inertia to members and increase adaption of wide band gap devices.  The work will lead to the development of more high- performance power electronics systems across different applications, and leads to full utilization of WBG capability, resulting in performance unimaginable in today’s typical silicon applications. All of these examples illustrate the impact GRAPES research contributes through knowledge accumulation, student education, industry recruitment of students and technology transfer.

 

Broader Impacts:

   The GRAPES Broader Impacts outcomes were also significant. The Center added a third site with University of Milwaukee, Wisconsin.  Several international sites have joined, including RWTH Aachen University in Aachen Germany, and two universities in South Korea - Yonsei University and Korea University.  This expansion continues the formal establishment of the GRAPES Global Institute (GGI).  The GGI is a concept long overdue because reliable, clean, resilient electric power is every nation’s concern. Through this process, GRAPES will broaden the impact of its research, increase the return on the dollars that industry members contribute, improves the education of students, and brings unique perspectives to the IAB-driven research.   Within the last year, four new industry members were also added.  It should also be noted that a number of graduating students who contributed to GRAPES research projects are now employed in prestigious positions.

   As of today, GRAPES-Korea has already recruited four Korean industry members that confirmed commitment of this program for the next three years as follows: KEPCO (Korea Electric Power Corporation), KERI (Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute), DOOSAN (DOOSAN Heavy Industry & Construction), LG Electronics and additional companies have expressed interest.
   As a result of the continued success of GRAPES, along with other projects, the University of Arkansas decided to invest approximately $3 Million to expand the National Center for Reliable Electric Power Transmission (NCREPT) Test Facility which supports the aforementioned center as a primary testing facility.  NCREPT is an approximately 7000 sq foot facility used to test almost all of the technology developed by the GRAPES center.  The facility is shared by the site partners.  It has grown by approximately 5000 feet in order to accommodate additional testing areas, along with more office space to support students, faculty, and visiting researchers. 

    Among the most significant benefits for our members have been: 1. Better prepared students hired by industry at all degree levels, 2. New circuit design methods for equipment, 3. Materials developed for high voltage packaging, 4. Evaluation of materials for high voltage packaging of power devices, 5. Electronic packaging techniques for high voltage, 6. New control methods for power electronics equipment, 7. Proof of concept of new solid-state equipment ideas such as fault current limiters, power converters, etc. 8. Control methods for microgrids, 9. Battery storage interfaces (feasibility), 10. Techniques to use grid-connected inverters (such as solar inverters) as grid instrumentation for fault diagnosis, and 11. Design automation tools and models for power electronics. These are significant benefits to GRAPES IAB members. That’s why GRAPES IAB members are very engaged with the center, recruit its students and participate in the semi-annual meetings, webinars, and strategic planning meetings.
